title: Birodi Chhoti, India
text:
Birodi Chhoti (also known as Bidodi Chhoti or Beerodi Chhoti) is a village within the <a href="Laxmangarh">Laxmangarh</a> <a href="tehsil">administrative region</a> of <a href="Sikar%20district">Sikar district</a>, <a href="Rajasthan">Rajasthan</a>, <a href="India">India</a>. Formerly known as Swami ki Birodi, the village is 250 years old and lies east of <a href="Laxmangarh">Laxmangarh</a> and west of <a href="Nawalgarh%2C%20Rajasthan">Nawalgarh</a>. Bidodi "chhoti" (small) borders <a href="Khinwasar">Khinwasar</a>, <a href="Bidsar">Bidsar</a>, Bidasar, <a href="Birodi%20Badi">Birodi Badi</a>, Jhareva, Jogiyon ka bas, and Brahmino ki Dhani (Ramsingh Pura) and <a href="Bhoodha%20Ka%20Bas">Malio Ki Dhani</a> villages.
The village has an overall population of about 1,430 of whom most are <a href="Jat%20people">Jat ethnic group</a>, while the main "<a href="gotra">gotra</a>" of the village are Bhaskar, Godara, and <a href="Lodha">Lodha</a>. Other castes include <a href="Brahmin">Brahmin</a>, and <a href="Harijan">Harijan</a>.
Transportation.
Birodi is connected by a two lane <a href="asphalt">asphalt</a> road to <a href="Laxmangarh">Laxmangarh</a> and <a href="Nawalgarh%2C%20Rajasthan">Nawalgarh</a>. <a href="Nawalgarh%2C%20Rajasthan">Nawalgarh</a> Railway station, from Birodi is the nearest railway station, which is well connected to <a href="Jaipur">Jaipur</a>, <a href="Delhi">Delhi</a> and other cities.
There is a road between <a href="Nawalgarh%2C%20Rajasthan">Nawalgarh</a> and Birodi chhoti. Asphalt roads connect the village to surrounding villages and to <a href="Laxmangarh">Laxmangarh</a>. <a href="Camel">Camel</a> carts and <a href="bullock%20cart">bullock cart</a>s were formerly the chief means of <a href="transportation">transportation</a> and are being replaced by <a href="motorcycles">motorcycles</a> and other automobiles. Quite a few villagers walk to <a href="Nawalgarh%2C%20Rajasthan">Nawalgarh</a> and other surrounding places. In the rainy season, womenfolk can be seen bringing grass on their heads for <a href="cows">cows</a> and <a href="Eurasian%20Buffalo">buffalo</a>es.
